features.name: Workforce Engagement Management
features.description: Tools for agent scheduling, performance tracking, quality assurance with custom QA criteria, real-time monitoring of service operations, and back office time tracking for optimized team management.

unique_selling_points: AI-First Resolution Platform: Purpose-built for AI-powered automation with advanced AI Agents that handle complex issues autonomously, backed by 5 billion annual resolutions - the largest operational base for AI training in service.

Omnichannel Excellence: Unified ticketing across email, chat, messaging, voice, and social media in a single intuitive interface, enabling seamless customer experiences regardless of communication channel.

Enterprise-Grade Scalability: Proven ability to scale from startups to Global 500 enterprises with mid-market pricing, supporting millions of interactions daily while maintaining performance and reliability.
Developer-Friendly Ecosystem: Comprehensive API, 1500+ pre-built integrations, and powerful no-code tools (Action Builder, App Builder) enabling rapid customization without engineering overhead.

Human-Centric AI Philosophy: Designed to augment rather than replace human agents, with Copilots providing real-time guidance and intelligent suggestions that enhance agent productivity and decision-making.

founder_information.origin_story: Founded in 2011 by IIT-Kharagpur graduates Niraj and Nitesh, Hiver started as Grexit (Latin for 'flock') with a simple mission: solve the problem of email collaboration for teams. The founders identified a market gap when Gmail was being underutilized for business collaboration. Initially bootstrapped, they achieved significant traction through inbound marketing and product-led growth. In 2016, they secured Series A funding ($4M) from Kalaari Capital and Kae Capital. By 2022, the company raised Series B funding of $22M from K1 Capital and existing investors, accelerating growth and product development.

founder_information.origin_story: Founded in June 2013 in San Francisco by Mathilde Collin and Laurent Perrin, Front was created to solve the problem of customer communication chaos in organizations. Collin, inspired by growing up in a family where 'no one liked their jobs,' aimed to build a platform that transforms the traditional email inbox—designed for individuals—into a collaborative hub for customer-facing teams. The initial product launched in 2014 as a shared inbox for collaborative email management, and the company expanded globally with offices in Paris, Chicago, and Dublin.

plans.agents_included: External reviews mention a minimum of ~45 Superhero seats; actual thresholds can differ by deal.
key_features: Everything in the Hero plan, typically with enhanced support, strategic guidance, and/or more favorable pricing at scale for larger teams.
Deeper access to advanced AI and automation configuration, routing and reporting tuned for complex, high-volume environments.
Enterprise‑grade onboarding and success resources oriented toward large B2C and global teams.

plans.name: Task User (back-office / limited seat)
plans.price: TrustRadius and multiple comparison sites report a starting price of approximately 38 USD per user per month for Task Users, designed for back‑office and non-frontline roles.
plans.price_annual: Approximately 456 USD per Task User per year at 38 USD/user/month (billed annually), based on TrustRadius and comparison articles.
plans.price_monthly: Around 38 USD per Task User/month (billed annually), per TrustRadius and third‑party comparisons.
plans.billing_period: Per user per month, usually billed annually as an add-on alongside Hero seats.
plans.billing_unit: Per Task User (limited functionality seat, e.g., back‑office and non-contact roles)
plans.agents_included: Offered as an add-on to a core Hero deployment; number of Task Users depends on contract.
key_features: Access to customer context and tasks without full omni-channel handling responsibilities.
Support for back-office workflows that complement front-line Hero agents (e.g., approvals, research, fulfillment follow-up).
Lower-cost seat type helping large organizations extend Gladly access beyond primary contact center agents.

features.name: Unified customer timeline and profiles
features.description: Every interaction across voice, email, SMS, chat, and social is stitched into a single, lifelong conversation per customer so agents always see full history and context without juggling tickets.
available_in_plans: All paid plans (Hero / Superhero; Task Users with limited capabilities)

features.name: Omnichannel, natively built-in channels
features.description: Gladly provides native voice, IVR, SMS, web chat, email, Facebook Messenger, and Instagram Messaging in one interface, allowing customers to switch channels without repeating themselves while agents stay in a single workspace.

features.name: Customer AI and Sidekick
features.description: Customer AI and the Sidekick copilot understand intent, draft and send responses, summarize conversations, and take actions like refunds or order updates so routine work is automated and agents can focus on complex, high-value issues.
available_in_plans: AI capabilities across current paid plans; configuration and usage-based costs vary by contract

features.name: Answers knowledge base and Help Center
features.description: A built-in knowledge base feeds both agents and self-service experiences, surfacing high-quality, consistent answers across chat, email, and Help Center so customers can resolve many issues without contacting support.

features.name: People Match routing and Skills-based distribution
features.description: People Match and Skills route customers to the most appropriate agent based on factors like skills, customer value, wait times and current context, reducing handle times and improving first-contact resolution.

features.name: Liveboards, Insight Builder, and analytics
features.description: Live, customizable dashboards and reporting tools give leaders real-time views of queues, agent activity, topics, and SLAs plus deeper historical analytics to optimize staffing, scripts, and CX strategy.

features.name: App Platform and integrations
features.description: Gladly’s App Platform, REST APIs, and pre-built integrations connect ecommerce, CRM, loyalty, returns, WFM, and survey tools so agents and AI see order data, loyalty status, and shipment details without leaving Gladly.
available_in_plans: All paid plans (Hero / Superhero); integration availability can depend on contract and partner

integrations.api_type: REST APIs over HTTPS with JSON payloads, Lookup API, webhooks, SDKs (e.g., Chat SDK) and an App Platform with OAuth-based apps.
top_integrations: Recharge and subscription/loyalty tools like Smile.io and Yotpo
integrations.api_capabilities: Gladly’s APIs allow managing customer profiles and attributes, reading and writing conversation timelines, accessing channel messages and call transcripts, updating knowledge base content, integrating external systems via Lookup API, streaming event data (e.g., conversation opened/closed) to warehouses via Segment, and building custom apps embedded directly into the agent workspace using the App Platform.

unique_selling_points: Customer-first data model that organizes support around a single lifelong customer conversation instead of tickets or cases, reducing repetition and enabling highly personal experiences.
Native omnichannel contact center with built-in voice, IVR, SMS, chat, email, and social, avoiding the complexity of stitching together multiple vendors for telephony and digital channels.
Customer AI and Sidekick tightly integrated into the core platform, using deep customer context to automate resolutions and assist agents rather than acting as a detached chatbot layer.

Rich ecommerce and retail focus, with deep integrations into platforms like Shopify, Magento/Adobe Commerce, BigCommerce, Loop, and loyalty tools so agents can resolve order, shipping, and return issues end-to-end inside Gladly.

Strong usability and implementation reputation, consistently rated highly on G2 and Capterra for ease of use, time to value, and relationship quality, particularly for mid‑market and enterprise B2C brands.
target_audience: Mid-market and enterprise B2C brands with high customer interaction volumes
Omnichannel retailers and ecommerce/DTC brands
Travel and hospitality providers (e.g., airlines, online travel companies)
Marketplaces and multi‑sided platforms needing buyer and seller support from one system
Scaling ecommerce/retail companies graduating from entry-level help desks to a more robust CX platform

reputation.g2_rating_details: G2 lists Gladly with an overall rating of approximately 4.7/5 based on 1,000+ verified reviews, with particularly high scores for usability, results, and relationship, and Gladly has appeared in G2’s Best Software Awards and multiple seasonal grid reports.
reputation.g2_leader_status: Leader in G2 Help Desk and related CX grids with dozens of #1 rankings across categories in Winter and Summer 2024 reports.
awards: Multiple G2 Grid Leader and #1 rankings across Help Desk, Contact Center, Customer Self-Service, Social Customer Service, Live Chat and related CX categories (2024).
Included in G2’s 2025 Best Software Awards lists for customer service-related categories.
Recognized as “Disruptive Technology of the Year” at the 2025 CCW Excellence Awards.
Named “Best Overall Customer Experience Solution Provider” in at least one independent CX platforms buyer’s guide published by Gladly.

certifications: GDPR-aligned data protection practices with Data Processing Agreement (DPA) available
security_features: Encryption of data in transit and at rest using industry-standard protocols.
Regular third‑party penetration testing and security audits to identify and remediate vulnerabilities.
SOC 2 Type II–certified infrastructure and processes to ensure security, availability, processing integrity, confidentiality, and privacy.
PCI-DSS–compliant handling of payment card data, including redaction of sensitive details before data is sent to third‑party AI vendors.
Granular access controls and role-based permissions for agents and admins.
Support for Data Subject Requests (access, deletion) and robust data retention controls for customer conversation history.
Auditability and logging of key system events, API access, and administrative changes.
Secure REST APIs with token-based authentication and HTTPS-only endpoints.

founder_information.origin_story: Gladly was founded around 2014–2015 by repeat CX and security entrepreneurs Joseph Ansanelli and Michael Wolfe, who previously worked together at Kana and co‑founded data loss prevention company Vontu. Incubated at Greylock, Gladly was created to reinvent customer service by shifting from fragmented, ticket-based workflows to a single, continuous conversation centered on each customer, anticipating the need to combine scale, intimacy, and AI.

funding_history.total_raised: Approximately 235M USD in total funding across multiple rounds, according to ZoomInfo/Preqin-style data providers.
funding_rounds: Series F-type growth round of 40M USD led by AXA Venture Partners (AVP) announced in September 2024, tied to the launch of Gladly’s unified, AI-powered Customer Service Platform.
Multiple earlier venture rounds backed by firms including Greylock Partners and others, contributing to an aggregated total funding of roughly 235M USD as of 2025.

company_info.founding_location: San Francisco Bay Area, California, United States
company_info.employees: Approximately 130 employees (ZoomInfo, 2025), with LinkedIn reporting a 51–200 employee range.
company_info.employee_count: Mid-sized, fast-growing SaaS company (roughly low-hundreds of employees).
company_info.company_mission: Gladly’s mission is to put people back at the center of customer service by rejecting the tradeoff between efficiency and empathy. The company aims to deliver both scale and intimacy—“radically efficient and radically personal” experiences—using a platform that centers on customers rather than tickets and leverages AI to strengthen, not replace, human relationships.

market_presence.global_coverage: Customers primarily in North America with growing adoption in Europe, Australia and other regions; hundreds of brands across retail, travel, and ecommerce operate global customer service teams on Gladly.
market_presence.primary_market: Mid-market and enterprise B2C organizations operating in ecommerce, retail, travel, and other consumer-focused sectors that require omnichannel support.
market_presence.global_ranking: Frequently appears as a Leader in G2 Help Desk and Contact Center grids and is included in several “best customer service software” and “best help desk” lists for 2024–2025.

additional_info.founding_location: San Francisco Bay Area, California, United States
additional_info.employee_count: Roughly low-hundreds of employees with global remote talent and a core presence in the US.
additional_info.global_presence: Serves hundreds of brands worldwide, including global retailers and airlines, with customers operating contact centers in North America, Europe, and other regions.
additional_info.mission: To eliminate tradeoffs in customer service by combining AI and human support in a single, customer-centered platform so brands can offer radically efficient and radically personal experiences that drive loyalty and long-term value.

industries: Marketplaces and platforms with buyer/seller support
best_for: B2C brands with high conversation volumes that need a unified view of customer interactions across voice, chat, SMS, email, and social.
Retailers and ecommerce/DTC companies that want deep order, shipping, and loyalty context in the agent workspace and AI experiences.
Organizations seeking to modernize from legacy ticket-based help desks to a customer- and AI-centric CX platform with strong reporting and automation.
Teams that value agent experience and ease of use, and are willing to invest in a premium CX platform to improve CSAT, efficiency, and revenue from service.
not_ideal_for: Very small teams or early-stage startups with low contact volumes that primarily need a simple, low-cost email/ticketing tool.
Heavily ITSM-focused environments or internal IT help desks requiring deep ITIL workflows rather than B2C customer support.
Organizations unwilling to standardize on a single omnichannel platform or that require strict on-premises deployment.

risk_assessment.contract_flexibility: Pricing is typically quoted via sales with annual contracts and minimum seat counts for Hero/Superhero plans. While add/remove seats is generally possible, there is no widely advertised month-to-month plan, so contract terms should be negotiated carefully.
risk_assessment.data_export: Gladly provides REST APIs, export capabilities, and event streaming (e.g., via Segment) so customer profiles, conversations, and metrics can be extracted into external systems or warehouses. This mitigates lock‑in risk but exporting and reconstructing omnichannel histories into a new platform still requires planning and engineering effort.
common_complaints: Relatively high per-agent pricing compared with entry-level help desks, making it a bigger investment for small teams.
Occasional UI glitches or browser refreshes causing agents to lose what they were typing, as reported in some Capterra reviews.
Desire for more advanced or customizable reporting and Liveboard configurations in certain use cases.
Difficulty seeing, in some channel views, whether a chat visitor has left or replied, leading to uncertainty about when to close a conversation.
A learning curve around certain advanced features (routing, reporting, complex workflows) for new admins.
mitigation: Pilot with a subset of teams and negotiate contract terms (seats, ramp-up schedule, implementation support) to validate ROI before a large-scale rollout.
Use Gladly’s training resources and certification programs (Gladly Academy, admin and routing courses) to ensure admins and agents fully leverage the platform.
Invest early in reporting design using Insight Builder and Liveboards, and consider exporting data to BI tools for advanced analytics needs.
Design clear routing and closure policies, including chat idle rules and proactive follow-up, to reduce uncertainty when customers stop responding.
Leverage the App Platform and APIs to integrate existing CRM, ecommerce, and analytics systems, ensuring data portability and avoiding over-reliance on one vendor for all functions.
